summary: Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an acute and severe viral infection of the human central nervous system that is caused by JE virus (JEV) it is transmitted between animal hosts and humans by mosquitoes (mostly of the genus Culex) (1). JE primarily occurs in children under 15 years of age and the elderly when protective immunity decreases (2,5). the envelope E protein on the virion surface is the most crucial protein involved in virus-host interactions. the E protein consists of 500 amino acid residues, appears as approximately 53 kDa, and is N-glycosylated (14). each E protein subunit is composed of 3 domains based on antigenicity (13) a constant -barrel composed of 7 head-to-tail -strands maintains an immunoglobulin-like fold (18) it contains the receptor-binding domain, which is connected to the central domain I by a flexible region and is a major target of neutralizing antibodies (19). determining the cellular receptor is a prerequisite for future investigations into precise molecular events involved in JEV binding and entry into cells. isolated in Xi'an, china in the 1950's, and stored in a refrigerator ever since. the culture supernatants were harvested after centrifugation at 500 g for 20 min, 45,000 g for 10 min and 70,000 g for 4 h at 4°C. BHK-21 cells (1105 cells/well) were grown to a confluent monolayer in a 6-well plate in culture medium. the cells absorbed the virus at 37°C for 1 h with gentle circular tilting every 15 min. the fluids were then pipetted out, and the monolayers were washed 3 times with RPMI-1640 without serum. confluent cell monolayers were washed 3 times with PBS. treated with 1 mM EDTA in PBS (pH 7.2) for 3 min at 37°C. pellet was dissolved in Buffer M without -mercaptoethanol. concentrations of membrane proteins were determined using a BCA kit. the complex was incubated with mouse anti-JEV monoclonal antibody (mAb) 2H4 (created and produced in our laboratory) overnight at 4°C and separated through reacting with protein A/G agarose beads. the beads were washed 3 times with 1X IP buffer and centrifuged at 3,000 g for 5 min at 4°C. rabbit anti-human HSP90 mAb was used for blotting (1:500 in TBS containing 5% powdered milk) we then used OdysseyTM IRDye680-labelled goat anti-rabbit IgG (1:5,000; Cat. no. 926-68071; LI-COR Biosciences, Lincoln, NE, USA) gG (Sigma-AldrichTM Cat. no. C2306) was added followed by incubation in the dark at room temperature for 1 h followed by a PBS wash 3 times. the coverslips were thoroughly rinsed in deionised water, air dried, placed reversely on a glass slide mounted with mixture of 50% glycerol and an equal volume Hoechst (1:1,000; beyotime Institute of Biotechnology, Shanghai, China) immunofluorescence was observed under a BH-60 immunofluorescence microscope (Olympus Corp.) at 4°C for 2 h and FITC-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (1:100, secondary antibody; Bioworld Technology, Inc., St. Louis Park, MN, USA) at room temperature for 1 h. lentiviral vectors were packaged in the 293Ta lentiviral packaging cell line. we considered HSP90 expression inhibition over 50% effective as void of off-target effects. cells with reduced HSP90 expression were then subjected to JEV infection. the culture supernatants were harvested after centrifugation at 500 g for 10 min. the supernatants were then received a serial centrifugation in 10,000 g for 20 min, 45,000 g for 10 min and 70,000 g for 4 h at 4°C. cell monolayers were washed 3 times with RPMI-1640 without serum. cells were stained with a crystal violet solution containing 0.2% formaldehyde. cells were cultured in RPMI-1640 medium containing 10% FCS. the membrane-bound proteins in the supernatant fraction were condensed through further centrifugation at 36,000 g and 4°C for 30 min. the pellet was dissolved in Buffer M without -mercaptoethanol. a gel with a single band was minced into sections at approximately 1 mm3. the gel sections were immersed in a 500 l preservation solution. protein identity was determined based on a score of >30 from the homology search tool MASCOT. gelDoc-ItTM (Ultra-Violet Products Ltd., Cambridge, UK) scanned and analysed by gelDoc-ItTM (Ultra-Violet Products Ltd., Cambridge, UK) CLSM was performed (29) to detect the location of HSP90-JEV binding. well-grown vero cells were treated with 3.5 mM EDTA instead of trypsin. they were washed 3 times with PBS and were fixed in 4% PBS-buffered formaldehyde for 30 min at room temperature. after a PBS wash, the fixed cells were successively incubated with rabbit anti-human HSP90 mAb. each incubation step was interspersed by washing 3 times with an FCM dilution solution. each incubation step was interspersed by washing 3 times with an FCM dilution solution. the cells were fixed in 300 l 4% PBS-buffered formaldehyde. immunofluorescence was detected using a flow cytometer. t-tests were performed using Prism 5.0 software (GraphPad Software Inc., La Jolla, CA, USA) results Results Results Results of Co-IP and MS analyses The immunocomplexes formed by membrane proteins, JEV and anti-JEV mAb, were precipitated, washed, centrifuged and subjected to SDS-PAGE. Reference score Accession Peptides (hits) serial numbers listed in this table are not one-to-one matched with gel bands indicated by arrows in Fig. 1. the presence of HSP90 in the cell membrane binds JEV exactly on the cell surface. a membrane protein component both reacted solely with rabbit anti-human HSP90 (lane 1) mAb and JEV (lane 2) at the same molecular weight position, approximately 90 kDa. specific anti-human HSP90 mAb inhibited HSP90-JEV binding on the cell surface in a dose-dependent manner. mAb inhibited binding on the cell surface in a dose-dependent manner. yields were significantly inhibited (P0.01), particularly at 24 and 36 hpi, by 6.5- and 5.6-fold, respectively. western blot analysis results revealed a decreased HSP90 expression in vero cells transfected with an effective siRNA. the peptide sequences from the gels were quested in the monkey database but generated no matches. the human database (Homo sapiens) had to be used instead. the 95-kDa-molecule was probed as HSP90, with a moderate score of 60.3. AGE, vero membrane protein extract samples were transferred onto PVDF membranes and reacted with rabbit anti-human HSP90 mAb. a membrane protein component both reacted solely with rabbit anti-human HSP90 (lane 1) mAb and JEV (lane 2) at the same molecular weight position, approximately 90 kDa. confocal laser scanning microscopy was performed. a specific anti-human HSP90 mAb inhibited HSP90-JEV binding on the cell surface in a dose-dependent manner. a specific anti-human HSP90 mAb inhibited HSP90-JEV binding in a dose-dependent manner. equent sequencing data revealed that the 21-nt siRNA (GGAUGACAGCGGUAAGGAUtt) was complementary to the human HSP90 mRNA 1012-1030 nt (GGATGACAGTGGTAA GGATAA), which is consistent with a previous report (31). overall, the progeny virions in both intact and siRNA-treated Vero cell culture supernatants were detected at 24 (Fig. 4B), 36 and 48 hpi a single polypeptide must exhibit the tentative receptor activity, bind viruses without other membrane components and maintain binding activity in electrophoresis detergents. for a successful VOPBA experiment, a single polypeptide must exhibit the tentative receptor activity, bind viruses without other membrane components and maintain binding activity in electrophoresis detergents. HSP90 is a class of chaperone proteins that assist other proteins in folding properly, stabilise proteins against heat stress, aid in protein degradation and stabilise many proteins required for tumour growth. it is found in bacteria and all eukaryotes, but is absent in archaea (39) no accurate HSP90 structure is available, even though it shares significant protein homology with its isoform HSP90, which performs conservative functions in cells by forming homodimers. the NTD exhibits a common ATP binding pocket that is shared among HSP90 chaperone family members. suggested by the MS analyses, we only produced positive results under non-reducing and non-boiled conditions. the novel band at approximately 95 kDa from the cell membrane protein extracts was reacted solely with either anti-human HSP90 mAb recognizing the amino acid sequences 1–100 that correspond to the human HSP90 N-terminus. these data suggest that the HSP90-JEV complex formed as it was recognised by two different mAbs against the two respective complex infection inhibition test was conducted using IFA and FCM with a rabbit anti-human HSP90 mAb at various concentrations. the binding percentages quantified by FCM also exhibited a significant decrease (P0.01) from 76.170.69% (0 g/ml anti-HSP90 mAb) to 19.150.35% (20 g/ml anti-HSP90 mAb) the plaque formation assay results indicated that cells with reduced HSP90 expression produced significantly less JEV progeny, particularly at 24 and 36 hpi (5.6-and 6.5-fold less respectively) another report (56) stating that HSP90 is associated JEV assembly, but not during the adsorption phase, confirms that HSP90-JEV interaction at the attachment stage is the predominant factor for the decreased virus production.
